turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: Oh, yes.
We couldn't dispose off the volume of our business if we didn't have 85 or 90% pleas of guilty.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that let's say 85 to 90 -- 85 or 90% of the instances there are defendants or persons under arrest and their lawyers do tell them to plead guilty.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: But of course, Mr. Justice Fortas, this is after the lawyer has learned of the strength of the people's case and I don't think this has any relationship whatever to the problem of the lawyer talking to the defendant at the time of arrest or accusatorial stage.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's exactly what --

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: Because in my experience and I have dealt with hundreds of lawyers who specialize in the criminal practice, it is a rather obvious indeed to whatever if he comes into the police station, say to his client, “Now you go and cooperate with the District Attorney."
Every one of them and of course there are exceptions but they only prove and test the rules.
Every one of them will say to his client, and how he will say it, it depends only on whether he's a purist or he is (Inaudible) or not.
But in -- actually, he will say to them either to button your lip, don't talk or shut up or anything like that --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I understand --

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: He will dry up this fountain of possible evidence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.
But presently in our experience up to this point I suppose is based on those people who do have lawyers at that stage.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: Which stage Your Honor?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: At the investigatory or accusatorial stage.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: And may I ask what Your Honor's experience had been?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well no, I'm --

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: I understood you say your experience.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: No.
No, I didn't say that.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I said that our experience, experience of our legal process has been with limited groups of person or limited numbers of persons who have counsel at that early stage, isn't that right?
That is to say --

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: That's relatively right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- that most people don't have counsel at that stage.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: That's right.
That's relatively right, very right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, so that -- and that -- and I suppose it's not a coincidence between the number of people who plead guilty in the number -- and the number of people who have counsel at the investigatorial or accusatorial stage.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: I know Your Honor.
They may plead guilty because their conscience bothers them.
They may plead guilty because they have decided that for one reason or another including perhaps the model of reasoning, there's better off.
They may plead guilty because the District Attorney offers them a quid pro quo.
There are many reasons why a man pleads guilty.

But certainly, it is not a fact that they have been put in the possession -- in the position of pleading guilty only because when they were brought in the police station they had no counsel and just give --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Oh, I understand that.
I wasn't making that point.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: They must give --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I wasn't making that point at all.
I would have --

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: Then I misunderstood you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- doing really was trying to ask about -- I was trying to ask the benefit of your experience with respect to this statement that most of the -- so many people are now accepting without any thought and that is to say that lawyers would practically always advice their client not to say anything.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: I believe.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright, and maybe that that has to be broken down in two parts.
One is, what the lawyer's advice to the client is before the lawyers look into the case?
The other is what is the lawyer's advice to the client after the lawyers looked into the case?

And to my mind there is a question as to whether if a lawyer as he frequently does on the basis of what you said tells a client to plead guilty, what's -- must we assume therefore -- must we -- how do we reconcile that fact --

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: I don't think that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- that the statement that the lawyer would always tell the client to button his lip as you put it.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: I don't think there's any contradiction at all because a lawyer advises his client to plea guilty after he's talked to the District Attorney.
And a fair District Attorney will say to him, “Now look, this is what I have.
I have this witness who'd testify to so and so.
I have a testament from your client, do you want to see it?”
I get people see statements.

And as a matter of fact we now have in New York a statutory provision, Section 813 (f) of our Code that if the District Attorney intends to offer a confession and evident on the trial, he must give reasonable notice to the defendant before the trial and the defendant has the right to a pretrial hearing as to the issue of voluntariness.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But would it cripple the law?
Would it -- would it handicap law, materially handicap law enforcement if the person who was under arrest started talking to the police only after his counsel had talked to the state's attorney.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: Based on (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I'm asking of (Voice Overlap) your observation?

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: -- based on your experience, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_i_siegel
turn.label: Mr. William I. Siegel
turn.text: While of course, there will always be exceptions, it is my honest belief that a warning to a prospective defendant in the police station of bringing a lawyer in the manifold difficulties, practical difficulties, and those (Inaudible) and obvious that this will dry up the -- practically the whole stream of confession.
And I -- it's been put this way, if you want to equalize the defendant and the police, maybe you ought to do it.

But if you want to preserve the rights of an individual I think this Court should be careful as to how it defines its right -- his rights so as not to prejudice the total lives of the total community.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Siegel.
